content.description: a short but very pumpy route!   crux comes in middle of the route past a (wingspan) move,
content.location: far right of cliff, starts up on a ledge 20' right of tilted arc.

content.description: Up the easy corner past the oak tree, then up cracks and traverse right to pull onto the belay ledge with a bolted anchor (shared with Out of Gas).
content.protection: Light rack to #3 Camalot, bolted top anchor.
content.location: Same start as Arete and Out of Gas, at the easy corner with a big oak tree about 10' up.

content.description: Bolts not replaced. Route goes on gear, although a bit spicy! Could definitely be an ankle breaker.Very cool but awkward climbing up overhanging flared groove, then a super awesome but weird and scary move to gain a lip. Then big throw to to small incut protected by a bolt. Originally rated 12b. Hold on face is Much smaller now. Still 12a.
content.protection: Small gear and 1 bolt to 2 bolt anchor.

content.description:
This is a crack that starts just to the left of Dream Weaver.  It has been cleaned and makes for a nice trad lead (when dry). 

  The crack ends at the ledge below the crux of Dream Weaver, so the logical finish would be to continue up to the DW anchor. 

  This crack can be easily seen (left of the climber) in the "photo of Josh" posted with Dream Weaver.
content.protection: A set of wired stoppers.    Cams ranging from 1 cm to 8 cm.

content.description: super fun route with a short crux @ 2cd bold moving left thru slopers. then finishing up the top face of tilted arc.   If its feeling to hard look for a couple knee bars.
content.protection: 4 bolts to LO, stick clipping 1st bolt recomended.   there is a pin low at the start for a directional,,,helps keep the climber from smashing back into the belay line!
content.location: located on right side of the cliff. 10'down and right of tilted arc.

content.description: Farthest right climb on overhanging wall. A bit contrived but still decent climbing.Maybe a bit harder now than when it went up. I have broken a hold or 2. SORRY!!!
Just another link up, start Renascence, Make sure you extend the 2nd bolt then head right below roof finishing resonance.
Crux at bottom of route then sustained climbing to the top. My favorite at the crag.
A right-to-left linkup that joins the crux portions of Resonance, Renascence, and Ariel.

Climb the slab (Reincarnation, 5.9-) to the ledge, then take the brilliant steep headwall. Formerly an aid route now free. When you fall off the first move of the headwall, be sure to lower down and climb the slab again (crux).
content.protection: In-situ bolts and clips, should be inspected before attempting as this wall is often wet.
content.location: The overhanging headwall above a slab.

content.description: This climb is trick up to the 2nd bolt everything after that goes very smooth.

climbs.name: Out of Gas
climbs.fa: Alan Rees, Dorcas Miller, Ben Townsend

content.description: Climb the easy corner to the oak tree, step right, then more or less straight up a continuous crack system to a roof. Bolted anchor at the ledge above the roof.
content.protection: Light rack to #2 Camalot, thin cams, bolted top anchor.
content.location: Same start as Arete, at a big easy corner with a large oak tree about 10' up.

content.description:
The climbs in the Fireman's ladder area are at the far left end of Rampart Cliff and are currently listed in a separate AREA Fireman's Ladder Area of Camden Hills

  To get to the Fireman's Ladder area from the Rampart Cliff, follow the cliff down to climber's left, then continue down through a somewhat scrappy gully (careful of rockfall), then continue left.

 To get from Fireman's Ladder (Area) to the Ramparts' left wall follow right along the cliff base to a steep gully.  Up this 40-50 ft to the base of the left end of the Ramparts.

Every thing goes very smoothly till you get to the ledge. Once at the ledge you can either go left up the arete or head straight up. I feel that the climb was originally intended to go straight up but I wasn't able to figure out the moves. If you go left towards the arete. I feel that you knock the climb down a letter grade and a number grade to a 10a/b. The crux this way is very pumpy and a fall could result in a dangerous swing into the ledge.
content.location: Follow the Jack Williams trail till you come to a stack of rocks. Take a hard left and follow the deer trail till you get to the Cliff

content.description: From the big ledge, climb the shallow right-facing corner to a bulge (crux) and pull up onto the slab above. Move up and right, using a right-leaning crack, to the Prospero anchor.
content.protection: Two bolts, light rack to 1", fixed anchor at top.
content.location: Start just left of Prospero, below a short right-facing corner.

content.description: Fun but funky climbing- right knee bars (pad) helpful from last bolt to anchor!
content.location: Start 15' left of Dream weaver, follow a slab past to bolts to a ledge. Pull up to a second ledga at a v -grooved crack -- work ur way up to last bolt! Look for some knee bars from here to top!

content.description: Climb to the right of Dream Weaver. Great line up overhanging wall. Gained by climbing the lower part of Dream Weaver and then tending right out overhanging face. Great 11D. Crux at start and at last move.

Start to the right of the easy slab below the right headwall, near a big tree a short way up the cliff.  

  Technical climbing goes up and left out the exposed slab and up the striking arete. Fun tippy toey, climbing.
content.protection: 4 bolts to anchors.Maybe a couple small pieces too if not comfortable at the grade.

content.description: Boulder up to the big ledge (or scramble up from its right end), then climb the short arching crack. Pull up onto the arete (crux) and follow it past horizontals to a bolted lower-off anchor.
content.protection: Light rack to 1", bolted lower-off anchor.
content.location: Start below the right edge of the Prospero slab. The route follows a short arching crack and then climbs the arete.Note: the bolt to the left is for a different route.

content.description: A great little crag about 80ft feet in height. A little bit of a hike to get there but well worth it
